intro: Crepis andryaloides, commonly known as the narrowleaf mouse-ear, is a flowering plant native to the mountainous regions of Europe and western Asia. It is a member of the Asteraceae family, characterized by its composite flower heads that consist of both ray and disk florets. The plant typically grows in rocky or gravelly soils and is often found in alpine or subalpine habitats. It has basal leaves that are narrow and grass-like, with hairy stems that bear small, inconspicuous flowers. Crepis andryaloides is known for its ability to thrive in harsh environmental conditions, making it a resilient and hardy species.
